para.sentence: Legendre’s relation (19.7.1) can be written R_{F}\left(0,z+1,z\right)R_{D}\left(0,z+1,1\right)+R_{D}\left(0,z+1,z\right)R_ {F}\left(0,z+1,1\right)=3\pi/(2z), if z\in\mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,0].
The case z=1 shows that the product of the two lemniscate constants, (19.20.2) and (19.20.22), is \pi/4.
The complete cases of R_{F} and R_{G} have connection formulas resulting from those for the Gauss hypergeometric function (Erdélyi et al. (1953a, §2.9)).

Upper signs apply if 0<\operatorname{ph}z<\pi , and lower signs if -\pi<\operatorname{ph}z<0 : R_{F}\left(0,z-1,z\right)=R_{F}\left(0,1-z,1\right)\mp\mathrm{i}\!R_{F}\left(0 ,z,1\right), 2\!R_{G}\left(0,z-1,z\right)=2\!R_{G}\left(0,1-z,1\right)\pm\mathrm{i}2\!R_{G} \left(0,z,1\right)+(z-1)R_{F}\left(0,1-z,1\right)\mp\mathrm{i}z\!R_{F}\left(0, z,1\right).
Let y , z , and p be positive and distinct, and permute y and z to ensure that y does not lie between z and p.

The complete case of R_{J} can be expressed in terms of R_{F} and R_{D} : (\sqrt{rp}/z)R_{J}\left(0,y,z,p\right)={(r-1)}R_{F}\left(0,y,z\right)R_{D} \left(p,rz,z\right)+R_{D}\left(0,y,z\right)R_{F}\left(p,rz,z\right), if r=(y-p)/(y-z)>0.
If 0<p<z and y=z+1 , then as p\to 0 (19.21.6) reduces to Legendre’s relation (19.21.1).

R_{D}\left(x,y,z\right) is symmetric only in x and y , but either (nonzero) x or (nonzero) y can be moved to the third position by using (x-y)R_{D}\left(y,z,x\right)+(z-y)R_{D}\left(x,y,z\right)=3\!R_{F}\left(x,y,z \right)-3\sqrt{y/(xz)}, or the corresponding equation with x and y interchanged. R_{D}\left(y,z,x\right)+R_{D}\left(z,x,y\right)+R_{D}\left(x,y,z\right)=3(xyz) ^{-1/2}, , xR_{D}\left(y,z,x\right)+yR_{D}\left(z,x,y\right)+zR_{D}\left(x,y,z\right)=3\! R_{F}\left(x,y,z\right).

Because R_{G} is completely symmetric, x,y,z can be permuted on the right-hand side of (19.21.10) so that (x-z)(y-z)\leq 0 if the variables are real, thereby avoiding cancellations when R_{G} is calculated from R_{F} and R_{D} (see §19.36(i)).

6\!R_{G}\left(x,y,z\right)=3(x+y+z)R_{F}\left(x,y,z\right)-\sum x^{2}R_{D} \left(y,z,x\right)=\sum x(y+z)R_{D}\left(y,z,x\right), where both summations extend over the three cyclic permutations of x,y,z.
Connection formulas for R_{-a}\left(\mathbf{b};\mathbf{z}\right) are given inCarlson (1977b, pp. 99, 101, and 123–124).

Let x,y,z be real and nonnegative, with at most one of them 0. Change-of-parameter relations can be used to shift the parameter p of R_{J} from either circular region to the other, or from either hyperbolic region to the other (§19.20(iii)).
The latter case allows evaluation of Cauchy principal values (see (19.20.14)).

(p-x)R_{J}\left(x,y,z,p\right)+(q-x)R_{J}\left(x,y,z,q\right)=3\!R_{F}\left(x, y,z\right)-3\!R_{C}\left(\xi,\eta\right), where (p-x)(q-x)=(y-x)(z-x),\xi=yz/x,\eta=pq/x, and x,y,z may be permuted. Also, \eta-\xi=p+q-y-z=\frac{(p-y)(p-z)}{p-x}=\frac{(q-y)(q-z)}{q-x}=\frac{(p-y)(q-y )}{x-y}=\frac{(p-z)(q-z)}{x-z}.
For each value of p , permutation of x,y,z produces three values of q , one of which lies in the same region as p and two lie in the other region of the same type.

In (19.21.12), if x is the largest (smallest) of x,y , and z , then p and q lie in the same region if it is circular (hyperbolic); otherwise p and q lie in different regions, both circular or both hyperbolic.
If x=0 , then \xi=\eta=\infty and R_{C}\left(\xi,\eta\right)=0 ; hence pR_{J}\left(0,y,z,p\right)+qR_{J}\left(0,y,z,q\right)=3\!R_{F}\left(0,y,z \right), if pq=yz.
